issue.title: restart discv5
issue.body:
When discovery fails to be seeded with bootstrap/fallback nodes, it
never recovers.

This commit changes the behavior so that status-go retries fetching
bootnodes, and restarts discovery when that happens.

It also sets the default DNS to cloudflare, not great, but as a quick fix for mobile.

I have made some changes to vendor/ one PR is out, https://github.com/waku-org/go-discover/pull/3
but the other one (waku-org/go-waku), relies on the updated go-discover, but you can look at vendor/ for the changes, they are pretty trivial.

issue.title: Add privacy options component
issue.body:
fixes #14122 

### Summary

Implements Privacy Option component


### Review notes

You may notice that this PR also implements a radio button.
This has been done because the radio button on `quo2.components.selectors` is not idempotent and has its state managed internally, behaving more like a checkbox than a radio.
In order to properly implement a set of option where the user can pick only one at a time, and since refactoring other components is outside the scope of this issue, a radio button has been implemented provisionally.


#### Platforms

- Android
- iOS

#### Areas that maybe impacted

##### Functional

- public chats
- group chats


### Steps to test

- Open Status
- Open Quo2 preview, select `privacy` under `settings`
- Test different values for the components

status: ready

issue.title: feat(waku2): peer exchange
issue.body:
This adds the [34/WAKU2-PEER-EXCHANGE](https://rfc.vac.dev/spec/34/) feature to status-go.

The way it works right now is by choosing a random node as peer exchange node as long as it has these characteristics:
- It was obtained via DNS Discovery
- It supports peer exchange protocol

The reason why I only chose from DNS Discovery nodes is to use a 'curated' set of nodes to ask peers from, instead of choosing any random peer status-go might have connected to that has peer exchange support.

Then, it will take the number of connected Relay nodes, and compare it against the max number of peers that can be discovered, to get the number of peers to request from this PX node. Currently I don't know if peer exchange should be used for light clients as well (we need to define also which criteria is going to be used to select filter and lightpush nodes)

issue.title: Setup autorelay
issue.body:
This commit setups AutoRelay and Hole punching.

What we observed using this code:
1) With a static address for auto relay, a hole punching session was setup successfully between two peers behind NAT and no UPnP.
This happened without asking the peers to connect directly, so the peer must have discovered themselves somehow.

I haven't replicated yet using the dynamic PeerSource, but I will try in the meantime, though it should work just the same as the same nodes are discovered.

issue.title: fix: group messages delivery
issue.body:
Creating group `v1protocol.NewGroupWithEvents` from `message.Events` is not always successful due to incomplete membership updates state. This happens, because group messages are encoded together with **abridged** membership updates and these updates may not contain all necessary events to recreate full members list. If some of the properties of the group chat is changed by one of the members who is not on abridged members list then message handler will fail, resulting in receiver not seeing any new group chat messages.

Solution is simple, it is to first merge existing group events with updated group events and only then validate created group which should contain full list of members.

fixes: status-im/status-desktop#8263

issue.title: feat(CommunitiesManager): introduce `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages` API
issue.body:
Prior to this commit we had a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrent()` API which takes a `startDate`, an `endDate` and a `partition` to create a bunch of message archives, given a certain time range.

The function expects the messages to live in the database, which means, all messages that need to be archived have to be saved there at some point.

This turns out to be an issue when importing communities from third party services, where, sometimes, there are several thousands of messages including attachment payloads, that have to be save to the database first.

There are only two options to get the messages into the database:

1. Make one write operation with all messages - this slow, takes a long time and blocks the database until done
2. Create message chunks and perform multiple write operations - this is also slow, takes long but makes the database a bit more responsive as it's many smaller operations instead of one big one

Option 2) turned out to not be super feasible either as sometimes, inserting even a single such message can take up to 10 seconds (depending on payload)

Which brings me to the third option.

**A third option** is to not store those imported messages as waku message into the database, just to later query them again to create the archives, but instead create the archives right away from all the messages that have been loaded into memory.

This is significantly faster and doesn't block the database.

To make this possible, this commit introduces
a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages()` API, and a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromDB()` API which can be used for different use cases.

issue.title: restart discv5
issue.body:
When discovery fails to be seeded with bootstrap/fallback nodes, it
never recovers.

This commit changes the behavior so that status-go retries fetching
bootnodes, and restarts discovery when that happens.

It also sets the default DNS to cloudflare, not great, but as a quick fix for mobile.

I have made some changes to vendor/ one PR is out, https://github.com/waku-org/go-discover/pull/3
but the other one (waku-org/go-waku), relies on the updated go-discover, but you can look at vendor/ for the changes, they are pretty trivial.

issue.title: Add privacy options component
issue.body:
fixes #14122 

### Summary

Implements Privacy Option component


### Review notes

You may notice that this PR also implements a radio button.
This has been done because the radio button on `quo2.components.selectors` is not idempotent and has its state managed internally, behaving more like a checkbox than a radio.
In order to properly implement a set of option where the user can pick only one at a time, and since refactoring other components is outside the scope of this issue, a radio button has been implemented provisionally.


#### Platforms

- Android
- iOS

#### Areas that maybe impacted

##### Functional

- public chats
- group chats


### Steps to test

- Open Status
- Open Quo2 preview, select `privacy` under `settings`
- Test different values for the components

issue.title: feat(waku2): peer exchange
issue.body:
This adds the [34/WAKU2-PEER-EXCHANGE](https://rfc.vac.dev/spec/34/) feature to status-go.

The way it works right now is by choosing a random node as peer exchange node as long as it has these characteristics:
- It was obtained via DNS Discovery
- It supports peer exchange protocol

The reason why I only chose from DNS Discovery nodes is to use a 'curated' set of nodes to ask peers from, instead of choosing any random peer status-go might have connected to that has peer exchange support.

Then, it will take the number of connected Relay nodes, and compare it against the max number of peers that can be discovered, to get the number of peers to request from this PX node. Currently I don't know if peer exchange should be used for light clients as well (we need to define also which criteria is going to be used to select filter and lightpush nodes)

issue.title: fix: group messages delivery
issue.body:
Creating group `v1protocol.NewGroupWithEvents` from `message.Events` is not always successful due to incomplete membership updates state. This happens, because group messages are encoded together with **abridged** membership updates and these updates may not contain all necessary events to recreate full members list. If some of the properties of the group chat is changed by one of the members who is not on abridged members list then message handler will fail, resulting in receiver not seeing any new group chat messages.

Solution is simple, it is to first merge existing group events with updated group events and only then validate created group which should contain full list of members.

fixes: status-im/status-desktop#8263

issue.title: feat(CommunitiesManager): introduce `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages` API
issue.body:
Prior to this commit we had a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrent()` API which takes a `startDate`, an `endDate` and a `partition` to create a bunch of message archives, given a certain time range.

The function expects the messages to live in the database, which means, all messages that need to be archived have to be saved there at some point.

This turns out to be an issue when importing communities from third party services, where, sometimes, there are several thousands of messages including attachment payloads, that have to be save to the database first.

There are only two options to get the messages into the database:

1. Make one write operation with all messages - this slow, takes a long time and blocks the database until done
2. Create message chunks and perform multiple write operations - this is also slow, takes long but makes the database a bit more responsive as it's many smaller operations instead of one big one

Option 2) turned out to not be super feasible either as sometimes, inserting even a single such message can take up to 10 seconds (depending on payload)

Which brings me to the third option.

**A third option** is to not store those imported messages as waku message into the database, just to later query them again to create the archives, but instead create the archives right away from all the messages that have been loaded into memory.

This is significantly faster and doesn't block the database.

To make this possible, this commit introduces
a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages()` API, and a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromDB()` API which can be used for different use cases.

This commit changes the behavior so that status-go retries fetching

I have made some changes to vendor/ one PR is out, https://github.com/waku-org/go-discover/pull/3

issue.title: Add privacy options component
issue.body:
fixes #14122 

### Summary

Implements Privacy Option component


### Review notes

You may notice that this PR also implements a radio button.
This has been done because the radio button on `quo2.components.selectors` is not idempotent and has its state managed internally, behaving more like a checkbox than a radio.
In order to properly implement a set of option where the user can pick only one at a time, and since refactoring other components is outside the scope of this issue, a radio button has been implemented provisionally.


#### Platforms

- Android
- iOS

#### Areas that maybe impacted

##### Functional

- public chats
- group chats


### Steps to test

- Open Status
- Open Quo2 preview, select `privacy` under `settings`
- Test different values for the components

status: ready

issue.title: feat(waku2): peer exchange
issue.body:
This adds the [34/WAKU2-PEER-EXCHANGE](https://rfc.vac.dev/spec/34/) feature to status-go.

The way it works right now is by choosing a random node as peer exchange node as long as it has these characteristics:
- It was obtained via DNS Discovery
- It supports peer exchange protocol

The reason why I only chose from DNS Discovery nodes is to use a 'curated' set of nodes to ask peers from, instead of choosing any random peer status-go might have connected to that has peer exchange support.

Then, it will take the number of connected Relay nodes, and compare it against the max number of peers that can be discovered, to get the number of peers to request from this PX node. Currently I don't know if peer exchange should be used for light clients as well (we need to define also which criteria is going to be used to select filter and lightpush nodes)

This commit setups AutoRelay and Hole punching.

What we observed using this code:

This happened without asking the peers to connect directly, so the peer must have discovered themselves somehow.

I haven't replicated yet using the dynamic PeerSource, but I will try in the meantime, though it should work just the same as the same nodes are discovered.

issue.title: fix: group messages delivery
issue.body:
Creating group `v1protocol.NewGroupWithEvents` from `message.Events` is not always successful due to incomplete membership updates state. This happens, because group messages are encoded together with **abridged** membership updates and these updates may not contain all necessary events to recreate full members list. If some of the properties of the group chat is changed by one of the members who is not on abridged members list then message handler will fail, resulting in receiver not seeing any new group chat messages.

Solution is simple, it is to first merge existing group events with updated group events and only then validate created group which should contain full list of members.

fixes: status-im/status-desktop#8263

issue.title: feat(CommunitiesManager): introduce `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages` API
issue.body:
Prior to this commit we had a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrent()` API which takes a `startDate`, an `endDate` and a `partition` to create a bunch of message archives, given a certain time range.

The function expects the messages to live in the database, which means, all messages that need to be archived have to be saved there at some point.

This turns out to be an issue when importing communities from third party services, where, sometimes, there are several thousands of messages including attachment payloads, that have to be save to the database first.

There are only two options to get the messages into the database:

1. Make one write operation with all messages - this slow, takes a long time and blocks the database until done
2. Create message chunks and perform multiple write operations - this is also slow, takes long but makes the database a bit more responsive as it's many smaller operations instead of one big one

Option 2) turned out to not be super feasible either as sometimes, inserting even a single such message can take up to 10 seconds (depending on payload)

Which brings me to the third option.

**A third option** is to not store those imported messages as waku message into the database, just to later query them again to create the archives, but instead create the archives right away from all the messages that have been loaded into memory.

This is significantly faster and doesn't block the database.

To make this possible, this commit introduces
a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromMessages()` API, and a `CreateHistoryArchiveTorrentFromDB()` API which can be used for different use cases.
